text: Patient: I was gonna say something oh that uh you know I had – I got some sleeping pills from a friend of mine. He’s a former nurse- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -okay so he done retired and stuff, but he gave me two sleeping pills that I took – and please believe me, I took with my OxyContin pill. I was like here – y’all just don’t know. I was feeling so good because the OxyContin was making me feel good, then I took a sleeping pill, I went right on to sleep. I slept the whole night. I didn’t wake up until the next morning. When I got out of bed this morning, I felt so good. Doctor: So did you ask him the name? Patient: Um ro-ro-roe or ro something like that, but it was – it – I mean I feel so good. I slept through the whole night. Doctor: Restoril, Restoril is a pill is a sleeping pill. Patient: Okay because they gave me that Ambien. I took one of them and a half of them, I slept two hours and I was back up again. Doctor: Okay so want to switch the Ambien to the Restoril? Patient: Yeah I mean if it’s gonna make me sleep through the whole night to the next morning. I’d love that because- Doctor: Okay. Patient: -I when I get my sleep I’m more active. See that’s why I lost a lot of weight because of that. Doctor: Alright so I can make one change at a time. Which one do you want to go? Do you want to go with the Oxycodone change, the Percocet, or what do you want to do?

text: Patient: For what I have. Doctor: …this one, for prostate cancer, is to start with Taxotere or Docetaxel and that would be what you would get. Family Member: Okay. text: Patient: Well I guess... Family Member: How long would we have to do that for that just out of curiosity? Doctor: It’s a, I’ll give you the exact… Doctor: Yeah but it’s more for the monitoring and because it’s a phase one trial it’s a little bit more closer monitoring. At least the first few weeks. After that it goes down to once a month once we sort of get the comfort level that you’re tolerating it okay, we know all the PKs and the blood level things are done, then it becomes much easier schedule. Family Member: What are the, how often are you talking about? A couple times a week or? Doctor: Well the first few weeks it will be about once a week or so or once every couple of weeks after a little while. And then after the first couple of months it goes to like I said once every four weeks. Family Member: Kind of like we started with this one. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Because the first couple of weeks I came down here… Doctor: It was more intense and then it… Family Member: In the beginning. Doctor: And then it smooths off once.

text: Patient: Can I go to England and get it? Doctor: Or one of those countries. I think Germany or England, yes, one of the European countries. Patient: I could go over there and do it. How long do they treat you, though, for that? Doctor: It’s about four doses, a total of four doses every six weeks or something. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So it’s not, uh, it’s not a one-time deal. Family Member: Wow. Patient: Yeah, I didn’t imagine, no idea. Doctor: Yeah. No. I agree. Yeah. So I think you should consider going on the study because that is our only chance, at least in the U.S., of getting on the medication. If you don’t, we are no better off than what we started with. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But now is a good time to consider the study because your cancer is not going crazy. Okay? Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? It’s only the PSA is inching up, but nothing else is getting worse.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
